Weâ€™ve upgraded everything: medicine, space travel, warfare, communication. But education?
Still stuck in the industrial age.
Classrooms. Exams. Text-heavy content. One-size-fits-all lectures. Itâ€™s all based on a structure built to scale instruction, not understanding.
And yet, the world we live in now demands the opposite personalized understanding at scale.
Education today still designs for the â€œaverageâ€ student, the imaginary median learner who doesnâ€™t actually exist.
In The End of Average, Todd Rose explains how institutions fail individuals by trying to serve a generalization. In reality, people learn at different speeds, through different formats, and with different motivations.
Designing a system around everyone means it ends up serving no one well.
We learn by thinking out loud, by â€¦

articles.author: Rajat Yadav
articles.description:
ğŸ¤¯Feeling Overwhelmed by AI?


Everywhere you look, itâ€™s:
If youâ€™re just starting out or midway into your coding journey  like me, itâ€™s easy to feel like youâ€™re already behind.
âœ… What AI is great at:
Generating boilerplate code
Suggesting syntax
Explaining common errors
Writing basic functions
âŒWhat AI still sucks at:
Understanding real users
Solving open-ended problems
Designing scalable systems
Making smart trade-offs
Making a creative work
Example: AI can write a â€œTo-Do List Appâ€ in seconds. But it wonâ€™t know if your users want reminders by email, SMS, or psychic vibes.
Hereâ€™s how you beat AI: Play the human game.
Think like a problem-solver:
Ask better questions.
Understand the "why" behind the feature.
Design for people, not machines.
Build with context:
Example: AI made the image below using a simple prompt "give me image based on my blog topic" vs the the image generate with proper instruction (i.e. the cover image of this post)

Seriously, donâ€™t fight itâ€”use it.
Stuck on syntax? Ask AI.
Need test cases? Let AI write the first draft.
Confused by an error? Let it explain.
But always double-check. AI makes stuff up sometimes (you prob already seen that).
Want to stay ahead? Get really good at:
Problem-solving
Communication
System design
Product thinking
These are things AI canâ€™t fake.
You donâ€™t need to be faster than AI.
You just need to be smarter, more thoughtful, and more human.
Let AI do the boring stuff. You focus on building stuff that matters.
Liked this post? Share it with a friend whoâ€™s stressed about AI. Weâ€™re all in this togetherâ€”letâ€™s build smarter, not just faster. ğŸ§ ğŸ’»
Got more advice? Drop it in the comments! I'd love to learn more and keep my stress levels down lol.
articles.title: How a Developer Can Beat AI (Without Losing Their Mind)

articles.author: ncutixavier
articles.description:
Accidentally deleted a local Git branch before pushing it? ğŸ˜± Donâ€™t panic â€” if the commits havenâ€™t been garbage collected, you can still bring it back using Gitâ€™s powerful internal logs.
Hereâ€™s how to recover your branch step by step:
Git keeps a history of everything youâ€™ve done even deleted branches in something called the reflog.
Open your terminal and run:
git reflog

This will show a list of recent Git actions, including checkouts and commits. It might look like this:
a1b2c3d HEAD@{0}: checkout: moving from feature-x to main
d4e5f6g HEAD@{1}: commit: Add new login functionality
...

ğŸ‘‰ Look for the last commit hash (e.g., d4e5f6g) from the deleted branch.
Once youâ€™ve identified the right commit, you can bring the branch back with:
git checkout -b your-branch-name <commit-hash>

Example:
git checkout -b feature-x d4e5f6g

Boom ğŸ’¥ â€” your branch is back!
Git eventually garbage collects old commits, so try to restore the branch as soon as possible to avoid permanent loss.



Action
Command




View Git reflog
git reflog


Restore branch
git checkout -b branch-name <commit-hash>



By keeping this trick in your Git toolbox, youâ€™ll never fear accidental branch deletions again. Happy coding! ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»âœ¨
articles.title: How to Restore a Deleted Local Git Branch or Commit (That Wasn't Pushed)

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Turner Wright
articles.description:
The US Department of Justice is reportedly conducting a probe over Coinbaseâ€™s contracted customer service agents in India, who accepted bribes in exchange for allowing criminals access to user data.
According to a May 19 Bloomberg report, DOJ investigators are looking into the data breach, which Coinbase disclosed to the public on May 15. The exchange reported that a group of customer support contractors â€” subsequently fired â€” â€œabused their access to [...] systems to steal the account data for a small subset of customers.â€
â€œWe have notified and are working with the DOJ and other US and international law enforcement agencies and welcome law enforcementâ€™s pursuit of criminal charges against these bad actors,â€ said Coinbaseâ€™s chief legal officer, Paul Grewal, according to Bloomberg.

Related: New Zealand man arrested in $265M crypto scam tied to FBI probe
Though â€œno passwords, private keys, or funds were exposedâ€ according to Coinbase, the data breach resulted in social engineering attacks targeting users, including a Sequoia Capital partner, with losses estimated at up to $400 million. The attackers also attempted to extort $20 million from Coinbase in exchange for not disclosing the breach, which the company refused.
Backlash in the courts
The attempted social engineering attacks have resulted in Coinbase users filing several lawsuits against the exchange, alleging that the company mishandled their personal data. One user, a retired artist named Ed Suman, reported losing $2 million to the scammers.
Coinbaseâ€™s stock price fluctuated following the news of the breach and an unrelated probe from the US Securities and Exchange Commission over its reported â€œverified userâ€ numbers. Cointelegraph reached out to Coinbase for comment but had not received a response at the time of publication.
